subject: Re: [junit] Theories Usability
msgSnippet: Berin, I wouldn t use Rules, either. One failure per method is currently baked into the architecture of the Theories runner--I d welcome a feature request for
messageBody:
Berin,

I wouldn't use Rules, either.

One failure per method is currently baked into the architecture of the
Theories runner--I'd welcome a feature request for the right way to
make that better.

In terms of knowing what failed, the Theories runner should show in
the stack trace the parameters that triggered the failure. Is that
not happening?

David

On Mon, Feb 8, 2010 at 9:24 AM, Loritsch, Berin C.
<berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
> I haven't logged the feature request, mainly because I might not be using the right tool for the job.  What I would like to see is what I described.
>
> With JUnit 3, I adopted the test nomenclature of something on the order of:
>
> testMyMethod_withNullParam1()
> testMyMethod_withXandYparams()
>
> etc.
>
> that would let me see within the test report (particularly a continuous integration test report) what exactly failed.  If the null parameter failed its check I'd have to fix one thing (boundary checking), but if the XandYparams version failed then I knew something may be wrong with the algorithm.
>
> With the particular Theory I've written I need to know not only the class that was tested, but the attribute that did not follow the contracts for using the base class.  With only one failure that can't happen.
>
> I didn't think Rules was the right way to go, because the MethodRule objects were applied to the tests within that same class (unless I'm missing something).
>
> Theories at least gives me the coverage and assurance I'm after, but I'd like to get away from writing to System.out to figure out exactly what failed.  I would also like to be able to see all my failures at once instead of only after fixing the last failure.
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com on behalf of David Saff
> Sent: Sun 2/7/2010 9:48 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Theories Usability
>
> Berin,
>
> I do think that we should eventually have a way to operate at least
> optionally in the way you describe.  Have you logged a feature request
> yet?
>
>   Davi
>
> On Fri, Feb 5, 2010 at 3:27 PM, Loritsch, Berin C.
> <berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
>> Thanks everyone for helping me work through the testing challenge I wanted to address.  I've written a rudimentary ClassCollector that lets me specify a base package, what base classes I need, any annotations I need applied, etc.  I supplimented that with a BeanAttributes class that will collect all the attributes (setters/getters) on the class.  It's working very well.  Unfortunately, there are a few shortcomings with this approach:
>>
>> 1. I cannot easily determine what the actual data point combination was that caused the failure.  I have to write those values out to System.out because the test failure does not do that for me.
>>
>> 2. It stops on the very first failure, hiding many more failures that may still be lurking beneath the service.
>>
>> 3. The theory is the only line shown in the test report, so there is no way to differentiate runs which would handle the above concerns.
>>
>> What I would really like to see is that a new test name for each combination of data points.  For example if you had a @Theory named "checkAddWorks" that took two parameters and the data points [1,2] then I'd like to see a set of test names that look like this in the test report:
>>
>> checkAddWorks(1,1)
>> checkAddWorks(1,2)
>> checkAddWorks(2,2)
>>
>> That will address all of the shortcomings I identified.
>>
>> My code looks like this:
>>
>> @RunWith(Theories.class)
>> class TestMyTrackableContract {
>>    @DataPoints
>>    BeanAttribute[] collectAllAttributesToTest() {
>>        ClassCollector collector = new ClassCollector();
>>        collector.within("com.mycompany.incident.model").assignableTo(Trackable.class);
>>        Collection<Class<?>> matchedClasses = collector.recurse().collect();
>>
>>        List<BeanAttribute> attributes = new ArrayList<BeanAttribute>();
>>
>>        for (Class<?> trackable : matchedClasses) {
>>            attributes.addAll(BeanAttribute.collectFrom(trackable));
>>        }
>>
>>        return attributes.toArray(new BeanAttribute[attributes.size()]);
>>    }
>>
>>    @Theory
>>    public void checkSideEffectsOnAssign() throws Exception {
>>        // This is designed to ensure that setters/getters work in concert
>>        // and that setters set the appropriate message is sent
>>        if ( ! beanAttribute.hasSetter() || ! beanAttribute.hasGetter() ) return;
>>        beanAttribute.assertBalanced();
>>
>>        Trackable entity = beanAttribute.getEntityAs(Trackable.class);
>>        // Unfortunately needed to determine when things go bad
>>        System.out.format("Testing %s\n", beanAttribute);
>>
>>        Object original = beanAttribute.getValue();
>>        Object testValue = beanAttribute.generateTestValue(original);
>>
>>        // Ensure the setter works as expected
>>        beanAttribute.setValue(testValue);
>>        assertEquals(testValue, beanAttribute.getValue());
>>
>>        // Ensure properties are set and events were properly
>>        Properties changes = entity.getChanges();
>>        assertEquals( String.valueOf(testValue),
>>            changes.getProperty(beanAttribute.getAttribute()));
>>        assertEquals( String.valueOf(original),
>>            changes.getProperty(beanAttribute.getAttribute() + ".old"));
>>    }
>> }
>>
